questions.question: The final phase of the budgeting process is to?
questions.tip: Think about what the big picture is.
content: compare your budget to what you have actually spent
questions.ed: The best way to see progress is to review if your plan is meeting all your goals.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a long term goal?
questions.tip: Think really far down the line.
content: completing college within the next six months
questions.ed: Purchases and vacations are short term. College has long term effects but the act of graduating is short term.

questions.question: Which of the following is a clearly written goal?
content: To save money for college for the next five years
To pay off credit card bills in 12 months
To invest in an international mutual fund for retirement
To establish an emergency fund of $4,000 in 18 months
questions.ed: A clearly written goal should be as precise as possible to accurately measure success.

questions.question: Which is a fixed expense?
questions.ed: Clothing, electricity use and educational expenses are fluid in cost.

questions.question: Which is a common flexible expense associated with apartment renting?
questions.ed: Security deposits are one time costs. Apartment insurance and rent are commonly fixed price.

questions.question: Which deposit refers to money held to cover possible damage in an apartment?
questions.tip: Which term is most similar to keeping something safe?
questions.ed: Telephone and utility deposits are not related to apartments directly.

questions.question: A common moving-in cost for an apartment would be?
questions.tip: Think of associated expenses separate from the apartment.
questions.ed: Down payments and real estate taxes are related to buying a home. A security deposit must be paid before moving in.

questions.question: A long-term goal would be to?
questions.tip: Think about what would last longer in your possession.
questions.ed: Renting or moving to a larger apartment are short term goals.

questions.question: The agreement between a renter and a landlord is a?
questions.tip: Think of a word similar to renting.
questions.ed: A security deposit isn't an agreement. Mortgages and deeds are normally related to property.

questions.question: A common disadvantage of buying a home is?
questions.tip: Owning a home is a commitment.
content: restrictions on decorating and having pets
questions.ed: Restrictions on decoration and pets are fewer with a purchased home compared to renting.

questions.question: The home-buying process starts with?
content: obtaining an appraisal of the property
questions.ed: Effective purchasing begins with a careful evaluation of needs.

questions.question: The amount of a mortgage a person can afford is affected by?
questions.ed: Location, insurance cost and age may be related to income but do not in themselves affect mortgage cost.

questions.question: Which kind of mortgage has a very large final payment?
questions.ed: Conventional, graduated, and shared mortgages all typically have regular payments that change minimally.

questions.question: The charges for settling a real estate transaction are also called ____ costs
questions.tip: Settling is similar to ending which is similar to one of these choices.
questions.ed: Selling, mortgage, or possession costs are very specific while closing refers to the end of most transactions.

questions.question: The highest loan rates usually occur when borrowing from a?
questions.tip: One of these entities doesn't do credit checks.
questions.ed: Banks, credit-card companies and credit unions do credit checks on applicants in order to determine financial risk. This leads to lower loan rates.

questions.question: What is used to add funds to a bank account?
questions.tip: How do funds go into an account?
questions.ed: A deposit slip is the document that routes external funds into an account.

questions.question: Obtaining cash from an ATM is similar to?
questions.tip: What other option allows money to leave an account?
questions.ed: Only writing a check makes sense for currency leaving an account.

questions.question: A service charge on your bank statement will result in?
questions.tip: A service charge incurs a penalty.
questions.ed: A service charge is a negative event. This won't cause balances or interest to rise.

questions.question: A common advantage of using credit is?
content: ability to obtain needed items now
questions.ed: Credit certainly does not lower costs or chances of overspending.

questions.question: A person�s regular income is referred to as?

content: file his or her federal income taxes on time
use an ATM several times a month
request to view her or his credit file

content: pretend to be a salesperson to attempt to collect a debt
threaten to take legal action to collect the money owed
call a debtor at work even if personal calls are not allowed
call a debtor at home before 8 p.m.
questions.question: A example of a fair debt-collection practice would be to

content: obtaining permission to be late with credit payments
obtaining assistance from a credit counseling service
using court action to reduce or eliminate your debts
